I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  (i)  a  proposed 
programmatic  approach  for  the  Inclusive  Growth  through  Improved  Connectivity  Program;  and 
(ii) a proposed policy-based loan to the Republic of Indonesia for subprogram 1 of the Inclusive 
Growth through Improved Connectivity Program. The report also describes proposed technical 
assistance  (TA)  for  Supporting  Inclusive  Growth  through  Better  Connectivity,  and  if  the  Board 
approves  the  proposed  loan,  I,  acting  under  the  authority  delegated  to  me  by  the  Board,  will 
approve the TA.1 
 
2. 
The  program  will  support  a  key  strategic  pillar  of  the  government’s  medium-  and  long-
term  development  plans  to  achieve  higher  and  more  inclusive  economic  growth  through 
stronger  domestic  and  international  connectivity.  The  government’s  long-term  Master  Plan  for 
Acceleration  and  Expansion  of  Indonesia’s  Economic  Development,  2011–2025  (MP3EI) 
recognizes  that  the  policy  and  regulatory  environment  still  constrains  connectivity  and  related 
infrastructure  development.  Therefore,  the  MP3EI  includes  regulatory  reforms  as  an  integral 
step in accelerating economic development. The government has launched a series of reforms 
aimed  at  improving  the  policy,  regulatory,  financial,  institutional,  and  business  climate 
frameworks  for  connectivity  and  infrastructure  development.  A  stronger  enabling  environment 
for  domestic  and  international  connectivity  will  in  turn  ensure  that  necessary  infrastructure 
investments by the public and private sectors are more efficient, effective, and sustainable. The 
program  will  focus  on  supporting  the  government’s  reform  agenda  and  infrastructure-related 
efforts to accelerate improvement in the country’s domestic and international connectivity.  
 

II. 

THE PROGRAM 

A. 

Rationale 

Indonesia’s  economic  growth  performance  and  poverty.  Gross  domestic  product 
3. 
growth edged up to 6.5% year-on-year in 2011 (the highest since the Asian crisis 1997–1998), 
supported  by  sustained private  consumption,  stronger  investment,  and  expanding  net  exports. 
Nonetheless,  economic  growth  is  still  significantly  below  the  country’s  growth  potential.  For 
2014–2016, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) estimates a baseline potential growth rate of 
7.1%, which would increase to 7.9% if infrastructure development and economic reforms were 
accelerated.  An  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  study  also  highlights  inadequacies  in 
infrastructure  as  a  critical  constraint  to  economic  growth.2 Indonesia’s  overall  ranking  in  the 
Global Competitiveness Index is at 50 out of 144 countries.3 However, the country ranks only 78 
out of 144 on quality of infrastructure, far below its overall ranking, implying that infrastructure is 
a  drag  on  the  country’s  competitiveness  (Figure 1a).  The  impact  of  lagging  infrastructure 
appears  in  a  number  of  forms.  Deteriorating  roads  in  the  provinces  and  districts  increase 
domestic  transport  and  logistics  costs.  Congested  ports  and  underdeveloped  interisland 
transport  have  led  to  expensive  domestic  shipping  costs.  Congested  and  underdeveloped 
international  ports  limit  the  efficient  integration  of  Indonesia’s  manufacturing  sector  into 
international production networks. 
 
4. 
Poverty reduction. Growth of 6.5% in 2011 resulted in about 1.5 million new jobs being 
generated, exceeding the number of new entrants to the labor force. The quality of employment

efforts are needed to reduce poverty incidence further. About 62% of the employed labor force 
(about 68.2 million people) still works in the informal sector, where wages and job security are 
low. Poverty incidence fell to 12% in March 2012, from 12.5% in March 2011. While the overall 
poverty incidence has trended downward, achievement varies across the country. The national 
rural poverty incidence of 15.6% is still much higher than the national urban poverty incidence of 
9.1%. Poverty rates in some provinces in eastern Indonesia are much higher than elsewhere in 
the country—for example, 25.3% in Maluku and Papua (Figure 1b).

5. 
Inclusive  growth  through  better  developed  connectivity.  Alleviating  the  country’s 
multidimensional  poverty  will  require  not  only  accelerated  economic  growth  but  also  a  more 
inclusive  growth  process  that  provides  rural  areas  and  disadvantaged  regions  with  greater 
economic  opportunity  and  access  to  social  services.  Improving  and  developing  the  country’s 
connectivity  is  key  to  reducing  poverty  incidence  by  (i)  connecting  rural  areas  with  regional 
growth  poles,  thereby  widening  access  to  markets  and  services;  (ii)  connecting  the  poorer 
eastern  parts  of  Indonesia  with  markets  in  western  areas  through  more  efficient  interisland 
transport systems; and (iii) improving international connectivity to boost the competitiveness of 
the  country’s  productive  sector.  Combined,  connectivity  efforts  are  expected  to  have  a  key 
facilitating role in increasing employment, reducing the size of the labor force employed in the 
informal sector, increasing access to and delivery of services, and thereby enhancing economic 
productivity and social well-being, and reducing the overall poverty incidence. 
 
6. 
Convergence of government national strategies and ADB strategy. The government 
recognizes that lagging infrastructure, underdeveloped intra-island and interisland connectivity, 
weak  international  connectivity,  and  inefficient  logistics  constrain  achieving  its  medium-  and 
long-term targets of higher growth and faster poverty reduction. Strategically, the government’s 
National Medium-Term Development Plan (RPJMN), 2010–2014 provides direction for the two 
pillars  of  ADB’s  Indonesia  country  partnership  strategy,  2012–2014:  inclusive  growth  and 
environmental  sustainability. 4  Reforms  assisted  by  the  proposed  program  will  support  the 

                                                 
4   ADB. 2012. Country Partnership Strategy: Indonesia, 2012–2014. Manila. 

 inclusive growth pillar of the country partnership strategy. In addition, improving connectivity is a 
strategic  focus  of  the  MP3EI.  The  MP3EI  will  guide  the  convergence  of  ADB’s  policy-based, 
sector,  and  thematic  interventions  related  to  connectivity  and  the  government’s  vision  of 
accelerated economic development.  
  
7. 
Lessons  from  ADB  policy-based  loans  and  development  coordination.  Several 
lessons  from  the  previous  country  partnership  and  strategy  for  Indonesia  (2006–2009)  and 
support for policy-based loans were considered.5 Achieving tangible results with ADB’s relatively 
modest  program  requires  selective  support  targeting  key  government  priorities  and  use  of 
programmatic  approaches  in  coordination  with  other  development  partners.  Specifically,  ADB 
effectiveness  can  be  increased  by  (i)  concentrating  on  a  more  limited  set  of  program  areas 
where  there  are  clear  synergies  between  ADB’s,  policy,  project  and  private  sector  support, 
(ii) focusing  on  core  sectors  identified  by  Strategy  20206 and  emphasizing  sectors  where  ADB 
has  a  strong  track  record,  and  (iii)  supporting  operations  where  ADB  can  play  a  catalytic  role 
with good prospects for collaboration with other partners. The program will involve collaborative 
cofinancing  with  the  World  Bank.  In  addition,  ADB  coordinates  with  the  Australian  Agency  for 
International  Development  on  infrastructure  issues  through  its  Infrastructure  Development 
Initiative Project in Indonesia. The program builds on ADB’s earlier policy-based loans, notably 
the  Infrastructure  Reform  Sector  Development  Program,  which  supported  government  reforms 
to  improve  regulatory  frameworks,  open  up  key  infrastructure  sectors  for  private  sector 
participation,  including  public–private  partnerships  (PPPs),  increase  competition,  and  improve 
infrastructure.7 A key lesson is to simplify the program to focus on high-impact policy reforms.  
 
B. 

Impact and Outcome 

8. 
The  impact  will  be  to  reduce  transport  and  logistics  costs,  a  key  requirement  for 
achieving higher and more inclusive economic growth that is sustained over the medium term. 
The outcome will be more developed domestic and international connectivity anchored on more 
rigorous  coordination  and  regulation,  which  will  help  generate  more  and  better  jobs  and 
contribute to sustainable poverty reduction.  
 
C. 

Outputs 

9. 
The  programmatic  approach  consists  of  two  subprograms  sequenced  to  support  the 
government’s medium-term reforms to strengthen domestic and international connectivity. The 
program supports the government’s efforts in four core reform areas: (i) strengthening national 
coordination,  regulatory,  and  institutional  frameworks  for  more  effective  implementation  of  the 
connectivity  agenda;  (ii)  strengthening  intra-island  connectivity  to  and  from  growth  poles,  with 
optimal  use  of  resources  for  sustainable  improvement  and  maintenance  of  land  transportation 
and  networks;  (iii) improving  interisland  connectivity  by  stepping  up  efficiencies  and  service 
performance  of  domestic  air  and  sea  transportation;  and  (iv)  enhancing  international 
connectivity by making Indonesia’s ports more efficient in handling traffic and trade volume. The 
policy actions (Appendix 4) have been developed to ensure consistency with the government’s 
development efforts and initiatives, as outlined in the RPJMN 2010–2014 and the MP3EI 2011–
2025. All the core policy actions under subprogram 1 were completed by mid-September 2012 
and  prior  to  the  effectiveness  of  the  loan  agreement.  Subprogram  2  will  continue  reform 
progress achieved in subprogram 1. The outputs of subprogram 1 will be:

Strengthening Connectivity Coordination and Regulatory Frameworks 

1. 
 
10. 
The  policy  reforms  will  strengthen  coordination  across  institutions  and  harmonize 
regulations related to connectivity and logistics. Execution and policymaking for connectivity fall 
under the jurisdiction of several ministries and local governments. The Ministry of Public Works 
has  primary 
intra-island  connectivity,  but  with 
decentralization, local governments are involved in infrastructure development and maintenance 
in the provinces and districts. The main authority for interisland and international connectivity is 
the Ministry of Transport. However, other ministries are responsible for some soft infrastructure 
such as customs, trade regulations, and connectivity within the Association of Southeast Asian 
Nations  (ASEAN),  including  Indonesia-Malaysia-Thailand  Growth  Triangle  and  the  Brunei 
Darussalam-Indonesia-Malaysia-Philippines  East  ASEAN  Growth  Area.  In  this  context,  the 
government  recognizes  the  importance  of  strengthening  the  policy  coordination  across 
agencies.  While  MP3EI  is  an  important  step  in  providing  strategic  policy  guidance  on  national 
connectivity  improvements,  it  still  requires  instruments  and  mechanisms  to  strengthen  its 
operational effectiveness in coordinating and strengthening policy reforms.  
 
11. 
Task  forces  for  connectivity  and  logistics.  The  government  set  up  a  coordinating 
mechanism  equipped  with  the  political  mandate  to  coordinate  policy  reforms  on  connectivity 
beyond  the  core  economic  agencies.  Presidential  Regulation  No. 32/2011  was  issued,  which 
appoints the Minister of the Coordinating Ministry of Economic Affairs (CMEA) as the executive 
chairman for implementing MP3EI. This regulation forms the basis for the establishment of the 
policy  coordination  mechanism.  To 
issued  a  decree 
establishing  a  high-level,  cross-ministerial  task  force  with  a  mandate  to  coordinate  policy 
reforms  on  connectivity.  CMEA  also  issued  a  decree  establishing  a  task  force  to  coordinate 
implementation  of  logistics-related  reforms.  These  measures  are  expected  to  strengthen 
coordination among agencies responsible for supervising activities along the logistics chain and 
resolve logistics and intermodal transport issues.  
 
12. 
Viability  gap  fund  to  support  public–private  partnership  projects.  Recognizing the 
limited  public  resources  available  to  meet  the  country’s  large  financing  needs  for  future 
infrastructure, the government has devoted significant efforts to attracting and leveraging private 
financing  of  infrastructure  through  PPPs.  The  government  has  made  good  progress  in 
establishing a supportive regulatory and institutional framework for PPP infrastructure, including 
(i)  the  Indonesia  Infrastructure  Guarantee  Fund  as  a  single  window  to  appraise  and  provide 
government  guarantees  for  well-prepared  infrastructure  PPPs;  (ii)  the  Indonesia  Infrastructure 
Financing  Facility  to  mobilize  long-term  local  currency  funds  to  finance  PPPs  in  infrastructure; 
and  (iii)  more  stringent  PPP  project  preparation.  While  some  projects  are  socially  and 
economically  desirable,  they  are  not  always  financially  viable  due  to  limited  cost-recovery 
prospects through user fees or tariffs. This has constrained private sector interest, underscoring 
the need to close the financial viability gap with public resources. The government is setting up 
a viability gap fund (VGF) to provide public-finance support to well-prepared PPP projects and 
so boost their bankability and financial viability. A draft ministerial decree for the establishment 
of the fund has been submitted for Ministry of Finance approval.

Intra-Island Connectivity Upgraded 

2. 
 
13. 
Improving intra-island connectivity is an important part of the government’s connectivity 
strategy  to  reduce  rural  poverty.  The  policy  reforms  will  support  the  government’s  efforts  to 
accelerate  development  of  intermodal  transport  systems  and  infrastructure  to  improve  access 
from  rural  areas  to  the  nearest  growth  poles  and  between  industrial  zones  and  ports.  Linking 

4 

 

 rural  areas  with  growth  poles  within  islands  is  constrained  by  inadequate  road  infrastructure, 
and  underdeveloped  railway  networks.  Although  road  investment  in  relative  terms  to  gross 
domestic product has again reached the pre-1998 financial crisis level, it continues to lag behind 
the  growth  in  traffic  volume.  The  government  recognizes  the  need  for  increased  infrastructure 
investment and creating the right incentives for local governments to construct better roads and 
maintain  the  quality  of  local  roads.  Meanwhile,  more  progress  is  needed  in  reorganizing  the 
railway  system  and  improving  arrangements  that  govern  subsidies  and  public  service 
obligations, and railway maintenance services. The rail sector has potential to play an important 
role in providing efficient passenger and freight services.  
 
14. 
Law on land acquisition for public use. The inability to acquire land for public use has 
been  a  key  reason  for  the  delayed  disbursement  of  the  government’s  capital  spending  in  the 
transport  sector.  The  private  sector  considers  the  land  acquisition  problem  a  major  source  of 
uncertainty in project development, costs, and implementation, lowering investor confidence on 
the prospects for road investment. It has also delayed the development of PPPs, particularly for 
toll  roads.  Overcoming  this  fundamental  constraint  is  key  to  advancing  the  connectivity  and 
infrastructure  agenda.  Consequently,  Parliament  passed  the  Land  Acquisition  Law  for  Public 
Use  (Law  No.  2/2012),  which  is  a  critical  step  toward  attracting  and  mobilizing  infrastructure 
investment. The absence of such a law in the past has generated uncertainties over costs and 
time  required  to  implement  infrastructure  projects.  The  law  is  instrumental  in  facilitating  PPPs 
across  various  sectors,  most  notably  for  toll  roads,  and  where  private  investors  expect  strong 
support from the government in resolving land issues. In August 2012, the government issued 
Presidential Decree No. 71/2012 to implement the law. 
 
Restructuring  the  railway  services.  Before  2007,  rail  services  and  associated 
15. 
infrastructure were a monopoly service owned and operated solely by the government, lowering 
incentives to improve services. Railway Law No. 23/2007 marked a crucial reform milestone that 
defines  and  regulates  railway  network  infrastructure  and  services.  The  law  separated 
infrastructure  and  operating  aspects  of  the  railway  sector,  thus  allowing  for  a  third-party 
operator.  The  rail  service  is  now  open  to  competition  from  the  private  sector  and  allows  new 
operators to obtain access to state-owned rail infrastructure. This is a fundamental change that 
will  have  a  far-reaching  impact  on  the  future  of  rail  operations  in  Indonesia.  To  improve  the 
operational  viability  of  the  railway  services,  the  government  issued  Presidential  Decree  No. 
53/2012 establishing a budgetary mechanism to transfer subsidies for public service obligations 
in railway services, and to reimburse infrastructure operation and maintenance costs and track-
access  charges  to  the  government’s  railway  infrastructure.  The  decree  covers  payments  to 
private  operators  that  are  competing  to  provide  noncommercial  railway  services.  Further 
implementing regulations of Law No. 23/2007 on the Railway Services Network are needed to 
support the restructuring of railway services. 
 
Performance-based  road  construction  and  maintenance.  The  public  expenditure 
16. 
review  of  the  road  sector  by  the  World  Bank  finds  that  24%  of  provincial  roads  and  41%  of 
district roads are in bad or poor condition.8 The performance is better for national roads, where 
only 12% are in bad or poor condition. To address this problem, the government has introduced, 
on a pilot basis, performance-based contracts for the construction of new roads. In addition, the 
warranty  period  for  road  rehabilitation  has  been  extended  to  2  years.  The  performance-based 
contracts  are  expected  to  be  expanded  over  the  medium  term  with  detailed  guidelines  to  be 
issued by the Ministry of Public Works.

3. 

Interisland Connectivity Improved 

 
17. 
The  key  objectives  of  interisland  connectivity  reforms  are  to  strengthen  the  policy 
framework to facilitate improvement in port productivity and to improve transport access in the 
eastern part of Indonesia. In a large, archipelagic country with a dispersed population, reducing 
the  cost  of  interisland  shipping  is  expected  to  make  a  significant  contribution  to  facilitating 
economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction  by  connecting  islands  through  lower  cost  and  higher 
volume trade and movement of people. At present, domestic shipping costs constitute a large 
portion of producers’ total costs, and are being passed on to consumers throughout the country. 
Reflecting  poor  logistics  and  inadequate  transport  infrastructure,  about  70%  of  the  rice  price 
differences  across  provinces  is  explained  by  the  degree  of  remoteness. 9 The  high  cost  of 
shipping  is  due  to  a  combination  of  inadequate  hard  and  soft  infrastructure  in  the  ports. 
According  to  one  estimate,  the  average  turnaround  time  for  domestic  shipping  at  the 
25 strategic  ports  is  2.7  days.  Given  an  average  sailing  time  of  1.5  days,  ships  are  spending 
about 75% of the total time between destinations at port.    
 
Information  and  communication  technology  fund.  Efforts  to  improve  interisland 
18. 
connectivity  requires  improvement  in  information  and  communications  technology  (ICT)  and 
systems  to  better  facilitate  and  complement  physical  transportation  services,  particularly  in 
eastern  and  rural  areas.  As  one  of  the  policy  initiatives  to  accelerate  ICT  connectivity  in  the 
eastern provinces, the government will establish an ICT fund through the issuance of Ministerial 
Communication  Decree  No.  21/2012.  The  fund  aims  to  improve  the  feasibility  of  private 
investment  in  the  provision  of  affordable  broadband  services  to  areas  that  are  not  yet 
commercially  viable,  which  includes  many  parts  of  eastern  Indonesia.  The  fund  will  offer 
financial  and  other  support  incentives  for  ICT  service  providers,  to  be  auctioned  on  a 
competitive  basis  and  structured  through  regularly  reviewed  multi-year  contracts  of  up  to  5 
years.  
  
Labor regulation on cargo handling. Labor costs play an important role in increasing 
19. 
logistics  costs.  So  far,  under  a  joint  decree  of  the  Directorates  General  of  Cooperatives,  Sea 
Transport,  and  Industrial  Relations,  all  labor  services  for  cargo  handling  at  seaports  are 
provided  through  a  dedicated  labor  cooperative  (Koperasi  TKBM).  The  regulation  effectively 
gave  monopoly  power  to  Koperasi  TKBM  for  cargo  handling  at  Indonesia’s  seaports,  which 
significantly  raised  costs,  particularly  for  non-containerized  products  such  as  agricultural,  raw, 
and bulk materials. To address this issue, the government has revised the joint decree to allow 
for more competition in cargo handling, which in the medium term will increase port productivity 
and lower logistics cost.  
 

International Connectivity Enhanced 

4. 
 
The reforms aim to improve regulatory certainty in customs clearance and reduce ship 
20. 
dwelling time. The bulk of the country’s international trade is facilitated by five main ports. The 
largest is Tanjung Priok, the country’s main international gateway in Jakarta, serving about 70% 
of internationally traded goods. Tanjung Priok also serves 29% of container traffic between Java 
and other islands. While Tanjung Priok is Indonesia’s most efficient port, its productivity is much 
lower  than  that  of  major  ports  in  the  ASEAN  region.  Ship  dwelling  time  in  Tanjung  Priok  was 
6.7 days  in  January  2012  compared  with  only  4.9  days  in  2010.  The  cost  of  delivering  one 
container  from  Cikarang  (the  nearest  industrial  zone)  to  Tanjung  Priok  across  a  distance  of 
about  56  kilometers  is  $750,  much  higher  than  the  cost  ($450)  across  a  similar  distance  in

 Malaysia  (from  Pasir  Gudang  to  Tanjung  Pelepas).  The  2012  Logistics  Performance  Index, 
which  measured  the  efficiency  of  logistics  services  for  international  trade,  confirms  that 
Indonesia’s  performance  is  much  lower  than  that  of  neighboring  countries  due  to  lagging 
infrastructure support.  
 
21. 
National  logistics  system  blueprint.  The  government  issued  Presidential  Decree 
No. 26/2012  for  a  national  logistics  blueprint  to  establish  an  integrated  and  more  efficient 
logistics system that would increase national competitiveness. The objectives of the strategy are 
to reduce logistics costs, develop more efficient distributon of goods across the archipelago, and 
to  prepare  for  integration  in  ASEAN  logistics  systems.  The  strategy  specifies  short-  and 
medium-term reform targets. The high-level task force for logistics will oversee implementation 
of reforms to achive the targets in coordination with MP3EI implementation.  
 
22. 
Indonesia  National  Single  Window  and  dry  port.  Improving  transparency  in  trade 
regulations  is  key  to  facilitating  international  trade.  While  efforts  to  simplify  export  and  import 
procedures are ongoing, the number of agencies and documents involved remains large. Thus, 
the Indonesia National Single Window (INSW) plays an important role in reducing the time and 
costs of importing and exporting by facilitating single submission, single processing, and single 
approval  of  import/export  documents.  In  March  2012,  the  government  issued  Presidential 
Decree  No.  35/2012  to  amend  Presidential  Decree  No.  8/2008  to  make  the  INSW  the  only 
reference  portal  for  cross-border  trade  regulations  in  the  customs  clearance  process.  This  will 
make  all  trade  regulations  accessible  to  the  public  and  help  to  streamline  these  procedures. 
Given forecast growth in cargo volume of 20% annually, port expansion will be necessary in the 
medium  term.  In  the  short  term,  the  dry  ports  in  Cikarang  and  near  the  industrial  district  of 
Jababeka  can be optimized. The government has extended the INSW system and services to 
Cikarang dry port.   
 
23. 
Policy triggers for subprogram 2. The program recognizes that achieving its intended 
outcome  will  require  a  coherent  medium-term  reform  strategy.  It  has  specified  10  indicative 
triggers that need to be satisfactorily completed by September 2013 (Appendix 4). The triggers 
will  advance  reforms  accomplished  under  subprogram  1,  focusing  on  implementation  of  the 
Land Acquisition Law, making the VGF operational, issuance of investment plan to improve the 
national road network, implementation of further restructuring in the railway system, completion 
of  contract  award  for  backbone  development  for  eastern  Indonesia,  and  establishment  of  a 
permanent agency to run the INSW. The program also recognizes the necessity for flexibility in 
the  reform  measures  for  subprogram  2  to  reflect  the  changing  economic  environment  and 
ensure continued strong government ownership of the reforms.  
 
D. 

Development Financing Needs 

The  loan  amount  is  based  on  the  strengths  of  the  policy  package,  its  development 
24. 
impact, the importance of the sectors covered, indicative costs of reform, and the government’s 
financing needs. Implementation of some policy reforms, such as the establishment of the VGF 
and ICT funds, requires adjustment costs. Effective implementation of connectivity reforms will 
also  require  capacity  improvements  at  related  agencies.  Government  has  doubled  its  annual 
budget allocation for the transport sector since 2010 to Rp 54.2 ($5.7 billion) in 2012 to support 
improved  connectivity.  Indonesia’s  gross  financing  needs  remain  high  despite  its  low  budget 
deficit and continued decline in debt-to-GDP ratio. In 2012, with a budget deficit target of 2.2% 
of GDP, the government will need to borrow Rp326.8 trillion ($36 billion), reflecting increasing 
debt amortization. The government has requested a total of $1.7 billion in policy-based lending 
from development partners, of which $600 million is from ADB. 

7 

 

 8 

 

 
25. 
To  support  its  reform  initiatives,  the  government  has  requested  a  loan  of  $300  million 
from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources  to  help  finance  subprogram  1.  The  loan  will  have  a 
15-year  term,  including  a  grace  period  of  3  years,  an  annual  interest  rate  determined  in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  London  interbank  offered  rate  (LIBOR)-based  lending  facility,  a 
commitment charge of 0.15% per year, and such other terms and conditions set forth in the draft 
loan agreement. Based on this, the average loan maturity is 9.25 years, and there is no maturity 
premium  payable  to  ADB.  The  financing  for  subprogram  2  is  currently  planned  to  be  $200 
million. The loan proceeds will be used to finance the full exchange cost (excluding local taxes 
and  duties)  of  items  produced  and  procured  in  ADB  member  countries,  excluding  ineligible 
items  and  imports  financed  by  other  bilateral  and  multilateral  sources.  The  proceeds  of  the 
policy-based loan will be disbursed in accordance with the provision of ADB’s Simplification of 
Disbursement  Procedures  and  Related  Requirements  for  Program  Loans10 to  Indonesia.  The 
World  Bank  will  provide  collaborative  cofinancing  of  $100 million  while  the  amount  of  the 
Government of Japan’s support is being discussed with the Government of Indonesia. 
 
E. 

Implementation Arrangements 

26. 
The  program  period  for  subprogram  1  is  from  June  2011  to  September  2012  and  the 
program  period  for  subprogram  2  is  from  October  2012  to  September  2013.  The  National 
Development  Planning  Agency  (BAPPENAS)  will  be  the  executing  agency.  The  implementing 
agencies will be the Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Public Works, Ministry of Transport, Ministry 
of  Communication,  National  Land  Agency,  and  CMEA.  The  government  will  form  a  steering 
committee,  chaired  by  the  vice-minister  of  BAPPENAS,  with  senior  representatives  of  the 
implementing  agencies  and  development  partners  (ADB,  Japan  International  Cooperation 
Agency, and the World Bank) as members. The committee will meet semi-annually to discuss 
interim  progress  in  achieving  agreed  policy  actions  and  milestones  in  the  reform  agenda.  The 
committee  will work with the connectivity working group, which is also chaired by  BAPPENAS 
and  responsible  for  coordinating  the  implementation  of  the  government’s  connectivity  reform 
agenda under MP3EI.  
 

III. 

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 

27. 
Impact and outcome. The impact of the capacity development TA will be to strengthen 
implementation  of  reforms  that  improve  interisland  connectivity.  The  outcome  will  be  stronger 
capacity  of  BAPPENAS,  CMEA,  and  the  Ministry  of  Transport  to  carry  out  policy  analysis  to 
inform decisions on connectivity policy needed to implement their annual plan and strategy.  
 
28. 
Financing  and  implementing  arrangements.  The  TA  is  estimated  to  cost  $1.18 
million, of which $1 million will be financed on a grant basis by the Technical Assistance Special 
Fund  (TASF-other  sources).  The  TA  will  help  the  government  to  accelerate  the  development 
and  implementation  of  reforms  in  the  four  core  policy  areas  covered  by  the  loan 11  by  (i) 
preparing  a  series  of  comprehensive  policy  analyses  and  notes  on  connectivity  issues  to 
develop  innovative  policies;  (ii)  supporting  the  establishment  of  the  new  INSW  agency  and 
conducting  initial  review  of  MP3EI  implementation,  including  an  in-depth  impact  analysis  of 
selected logistics constraints and MP3EI projects; (iii) supporting the initial work for preparation 
of  a  policy  framework,  and  an  implementation  road  map  for  private  sector  participation  and 
PPPs,  in  the  transport  sector;  and  (iv) developing  a  capacity  building  program  for  key

IV. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

A. 

Economic and Financial 

The  policy  actions  of  the  program  are  derived  from  the  government’s  medium-term 
29. 
reform  priorities,  which  are  crucial  in  achieving  the  government’s  higher  and  more  inclusive 
growth  strategy.  The  proposed  reforms  are  expected  to  stimulate  increased  infrastructure 
investment,  which  could  generate  additional  economic  growth  of  about  1  percentage  point 
annually  over  the  medium  term.  A  single  reform  to  reduce  the  dwelling  time  at  Tanjung  Priok 
port to 3 days is estimated to generate economic benefits of over $450 million (based on 2010 
prices).13  

 
Governance 

B. 

30. 
The government has made considerable progress in the legal and regulatory framework 
for  public  financial  management.  Since  the  enactment  of  the  laws  on  state  finance,  state 
treasury,  and  state  audit  in  2003–2004,  most  of  the  regulations  underpinning  the  laws  have 
been  promulgated.  In  2009,  the  government  achieved  its  first  qualified  audit  opinion  from  the 
External  Audit  Agency,  and  about  40%  of  ministries  and  agencies  achieved  unqualified 
opinions. ADB reinforces this momentum with continuing support to improve technical capacity 
and  controls.  Building  on  previous  programs,  ADB  TA  for  Strengthening  National  Public 
Procurement  Processes  has  been  committed  to  boost  transparency  and  efficiency  in  public 
procurement  processes. 14  Initial  findings  from  the  2011  public  expenditure  and  financial 
accountability repeat assessment show marked progress in budget controls and reporting. As a 
result  of  the  government’s  continuing  commitment  to  reduce  corruption,  Transparency 
International’s control of corruption perception index for Indonesia rose to 3.0 in 2011, from 2.8 
in  2010. 15  ADB’s  Anticorruption  Policy  (1998,  as  amended  to  date)  was  explained  to  and 
discussed with BAPPENAS.

D. 

Safeguards 

The  program  does  not  trigger  ADB’s  safeguard  policies  and  is  classified  under 

32. 
category C for impacts on the environment, involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples.  
 
E. 

Risks and Mitigating Measures 

The three main risks to the program, rated low to medium, are: (i) weak coordination in 
33. 
and between key government agencies; (ii) continued under disbursement of capital spending; 
and (iii) increased international fuel prices, which could divert government budgetary resources 
from capital investment to fuel subsidies. To mitigate risks (i) and (ii), the government has set up 
a  high-level  task  force  for  connectivity  and  tasked  the  President’s  delivery  unit  to  monitor  the 
progress.  For  the  third  risk,  Parliament  has  approved  a  mechanism  in  the  2012  budget  to 
increase domestic fuel prices should they exceed a pre-determined threshold.17
